I am now 20 and date a 21(almost 22) guy, I discovered 2 years ago I have endometriosis and we are learning about it (how to treat, the risks) to be ready for trying for a baby in 4-5 years from now.
Thanks to my genetics, the best treatment for me is the slowest one available, and I am going to start a stronger one next year(because 21 will be the best age for it according to my doctor)
I know it seems over the top to be worries at 20, but me and my boyfriend want kids, at least 1, so it's better to start my treatment early so we can be safe and have less complications on the birth :)
(Just sharing because there are women who don't know they have endometriosis, about half of us don't know. If you want to have a child, even later in life get a check up. If you're trying and you're not making it, don't just do fertility tests, do endometriosis too!)
Best wishes for everyone who's trying for a baby (or not)

I don't personally believe that women beginning menopause has much to do with a lower egg count.
But has more to do with the pituitary gland, sending out a signal to stop reproductive organs at a certin age.

Let's take Michelle Duggar for example, she has had 19 children. So for every 1 child she has means 9 eggs that didn't get wasted. The 1 that was fertilized and resulted in a birth. And 8 periods, that she didn't have; therefore the eggs stayed in her reproductive system. (And I know she's had more than 19 pregnancies, but they didn't go to full term, so im not couting them)
So lets do the math on this:
1 pregnancy = 1 child, and 8 saved eggs
So 19 pregnancies × 9 monthes - 19 fertilized eggs
equals 152 monthes menopause should be postponed. So why in her early 50's is she going through menopause, when she should have at least 12 more years worth of eggs? Thats just my 2 cents

Some important points not covered here:

- Raising another human being from infancy is a doorway to personal growth that might be largely inaccessible otherwise. One's personality, outlook, and perception of the world will be fundamentally different. And the change is not just experiential, but chemical too, and for both sexes (it first happens to women during pregnancy, and usually starts hitting men 0-6 months after birth).

- Sometimes people don't realize until after they had kids that they don't like having kids. And the flip-side is true too: I love being a father so much that I deeply regret not starting a family in my 20's (looking back, I see that I wasted a LOT of my pre-fatherhood years just being a self absorbed man-child).

- Women approaching 40 who are waiting for a man to have a child risk never having a child. You won't hear people say this very often but it's true. And it's not just a matter of biology; the older we get the harder it becomes to meet and adjust to new love interests.

- Maintaining a good relationship with your mate/partner is harder than raising the child.

- Counter-intuitively, waiting until you think you can afford a child isn't always the best idea. If people actually knew going in how much their child was going to cost, the average person would never feel $ecure enough to have one.

...and I'm sure there's more points to be made...
